content: Somehow managed to brute force 100% by using js bigInt and just doing b**e. Ofc it timed out on test 4, but not knowing the solution I figured good enough. Clicked submit and to my surprise I got a 100%. Weird bug or more processing time allocated for submission testing than live IDE testing?

You've hidden the hardest edge case in a validator (Validator 5). I think it's not fair to do this, since you should really have a matching test for every validator to give clashers the chance to debug their code before submitting.

It would be best to add a test/validator pair where the test has [[exponent]] = 0 and the validator has [[base]] = 0, to even things out.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Problème intéressant mettant en jeu des logiques que je n'ai pas encore rencontré sur CoC

I like this. a couple of points:

>   0 ≤ capacity ≤ 10^6
shouldn't capacity be strictly greater than 0? if capacitor is 0 the output is infinity/undefinable?

>   Line 1 : An integer capacity, the number of digits which can be written on the paper.
Nit: "paper" is inconsistent with "line" in the goal text. I'd say "written on one line"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I found the problem interesting and different than the usual problems in CoC.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think the puzzle looks fine now. One small weakness is that the test cases aren't intuitive, but I can't think of a good alternative, since people don't normally think about this kind of problem.
I'd like to see test cases that include 0
Fixed binary output and changed a bit the text, is this correct now ?

- Format "GOOD" and "TOO LONG" as constants because they are not variables

- Add a third possible output to avoid binary output

As stated in the contribution guidelines, binary output (i.e. there are only two possible outputs) should be avoided.
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/contribution-guidelines

Also GOOD and TOO LONG are not variables, they should be formatted as constants.
What if I change a bit by asking how many papers would be needed to entirely write the given number ?
That should be better I think.
